ygData.subject: Re: Introduction and an os x query

Robert, I had a couple comments about your implementation, which 
I'll inse=
rt under the relevant parts of your explanation below.

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, Robert Ziegler <rziegler42@...> wrote:
>
> My impelementation spl=
its the system into two parts:
> genetics and network.  A network is create=
d from the
> genetics, but the genetics cannot be updated from the
> networ=
k.  If the genetics change, the network must be
> reinstantiated.
> 

The u=
sual NEAT algorithm doesn't update genetics from the network 
either, so I =
am a little confused at what you mean to imply with 
this observation about=
 your system.  Perhaps you thought that 
regular NEAT does something along =
those lines which is actually 
doesn't.  In any case, it just sounds like t=
he normal approach.

> The genetics are implemented by an abstract Gene
> c=
lass.  Each type of gene implements the abstract
> class.  The system curre=
ntly only has two types of
> genes, NeuronGenes and WeightGenes.  Each gene=
 has a
> label which is a simple unsigned integer which is
> autoassigned w=
hen the gene is created or cloned.  Each
> subclass must implement a compar=
e method used to sort
> genes of each type.
> 

When you say "Each gene has=
 a label.." those sound like they are 
innovation numbers to me.  It just s=
ounds like you only use 
innovation numbers on the nodes, but they are inno=
vation numbers all 
the same.  You are inferring the uniqueness of connecti=
ons from the 
innovation numbers on their respective nodes, but in effect t=
his is 
still using innovation numbers.

> NeuronGenes are sorted by their =
label, thus they  must
> be created in a specific order: input, bias, outpu=
t,
> hidden.  Hidden neuron genes can come anywhere in the
> sequence, but =
must appear after the last non-hidden
> neuron gene.
> 
> WeightGenes are s=
orted by their output neuron
> connection label first, followed by their in=
put neuron
> connection label second.  The compare method for
> weight gene=
s is about thirty lines of code.
> 
> When the genetics are sorted, using S=
TL with the
> gene's compare method, everything lines up as expected
> with=
 innovations.  I only sort once, immediately after
> the genetics have been=
 created.  Both the network
> creation code and the genetic mating code dep=
end upon
> a well sorted gene sequence.
> 

I think you're just pointing ou=
t that with some cleverness you can 
get by with only using the innovation =
numbers on the nodes.  I think 
that's true, but it makes the program more =
complicated because like 
you said you need to do some special sorting of c=
onnections based on 
node numbers that wouldn't be necessary if you labeled=
 the 
connections.

> A genepool is implemented using a hash table. 
> When=
ever a new gene is created, the hash table is used
> to see if   
> gene al=
ready exists.  In the case of a weight gene,
> the hash function uses the o=
utput/input neuron label
> pairing.  If the gene is found, a reference coun=
t is
> increased and a pointer to the existing gene is
> returned rather th=
an creating a new gene.  Once each
> epoch, the genepool is purged of any g=
enes that no
> longer have any references to help speed up searches.
> 
> I=
t takes only seconds to create large populations with
> huge networks.  My =
large test case has a population
> with 5000 organisms of 100 neurons each.=
  It takes
> only ten to twenty seconds real time to create the
> populatio=
n.  The majority of creation time is spent in
> the speciation code, which =
may still be buggy.
> 

I'm not sure that taking only seconds to create a p=
opulation really 
addresses any existing issues with NEAT.  The creation of=
 initial 
population was never a significant CPU bottleneck that I am aware=
 
of, and using the usual innovation number scheme I'm not even sure 
if it=
 might be faster.  But in any case, the NEAT algorithm's 
efficiency is not=
 pinnedon the initial population so it shouldn't 
matter too much.

I don't=
 want to sound like I'm being overly critical of course.   
Doing NEAT in d=
ifferent ways is great, and I encourage exploring 
different schemes or var=
iations.  I think you may have done a good 
job just numbering the nodes, b=
ut I point out these issues mostly 
for clarity for other people who might =
be new to NEAT and possibly 
confused about what your statements may imply.=


ken

> 
> --- Michael Rosario <michaelrosario_2003@...>
> wrote:
> 
> > J=
ust wondering... In your implementation, if you do
> > not use innovation n=
umbers, how do you line up genes
> > for mating operations?  
> 
>
